div.p: Greetings. The letter, which your kindness has once again deigned to write to me after several months, was mentioned to me by Mr. Friedrich von Salis before I received it. He, returning from there, told us many things about all the learned men there, and especially about your kindness and cheerfulness. I received that letter, written on the fifth of February, on the 17th of the same month, so you should not be surprised if I am writing back somewhat late. However, you might wonder why I have not written for a long time; but there would be no reason for surprise if you knew what has deterred me from writing: the words of some people here, voices from your side coming to us, your long and persistent silence, not to mention the letters you sent to Basel against me; for I have nothing certain, only hearsay. From all of this, I easily perceived that I and my matters are no longer pleasing to you, and therefore I should not trouble an offended mind. Yet, I could not help but always love you, nor will I cease to do so as long as life governs these limbs, whether you write to me or not. However, since I see that my suspicion is unfounded and that your kindness wishes to have my trifles, I will write henceforth whatever seems not so unworthy of your ears.

Therefore, you have abundantly learned what you wish to know from Mr. Friedrich. For who could have narrated it more accurately or clearly? Although there is nothing now to write, I will write at another time. I will add this: our Confederates beheaded a certain captain of Ilanz, not so much because he led soldiers from the Confederates to Milan against the edict, but because he committed several thefts. I previously sent you a printed book, which our schoolmaster played with, and we are expecting it. Meanwhile, farewell, most esteemed man in every way, and do not cease to love your Philippus in return.
From Chur, on the 20th of February, in the year 1557.
Yours no less than always, Philippus Gallicius.
To the truly great man Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and brother, most esteemed by all good people. In ZÃ¼rich.
